dublin_core.dcvalue: We conducted a systematic review and meta analysis of the literature examining the relationship between driving performance and engaging in secondary tasks We extracted data from abstracts of 206 empirical articles published between 1968 and 2012 and developed a logistic regression model to identify correlates of a detrimental relationship between secondary tasks and driving performance Of 350 analyses 80 reported finding a detrimental relationship Studies using experimental designs were 37 less likely to report a detrimental relationship P 014 Studies examining mobile phone use while driving were 16 more likely to find such a relationship P 009 Quasi experiments can better determine the effects of secondary tasks on driving performance and consequently serve to inform policymakers interested in reducing distracted driving and increasing roadway safety
Associations between driving performance and engaging in secondary tasks: a systematic review.
